The College Student and the War
By HERBERT HOOVER
United States Food Administrator.

(From the Patriotic News Service of
the National Committee of Patriotic
Societies, Washington, D. C.)

To the college men of America I
address myself with confidence, a
confidence born of unforgettable
experience.
In the relief of Belgium most of
the actual work of the Commission in the occupied territory was
done by young American collegians. Each time a call was
made for volunteers many more
than asked for offered their services. And those that were chosen
performed their duties, not only
effectively, but with a spirit of devotion that made their service beyond praise. They combined idealism and efficiency. It is the combination that moves the world forward.
Today all the young college men
of America face,a special responsibility and duty. At no time in the
world's history has the technically
trained mind been at a higher premium. And this need for it and
demand on it will continue after
the war is over. Hence the young
man in college is faced with a serious problem. He must ask hinrself: Is the immediate need of me
by my country in my present stage
of training greater than this need
will be later, and when I have acquired a higher training? This is
a question the clear answer to
which cannot be indicated for all
by a single formula,..because the
young men in college find themselves under varying circumstances. Yet an answer in general
terms of some helpfulness may be
made.
To the younger men, the lower
classmen, only beginning their
professional training, I say: Keep
on with your college work. If the
war lasts long you will be needed
more later than now; and you
will be better qualified to fill the
need then. If the war ends soon
there will still be urgent need for
your help in the necessary great
work of reconstruction and rehabilitation. The moreadvancedyour
training, the more mature your
judgment, the more valuable you
• will be. So try to possess yourself
in patience and stick to your college work.
To the upper classmen I would
say: Hold yourself ready to respond to your country's present
need at any moment. Where you
see your way clear to make your
training useful do not hesitate to
follow the way. But you, too,
should remember that every additional month or semester of train(Continued on page 2, col. 2)

Dr. William H. Howell, professor of physiology at the Medical
School and assistant to Dr. William H. Welch in the direction of
the new Institute of Hygiene and
Public Health, has been selected
to head a committee of eminent
physiologists of America and England, appointed to try to find the
cause and a cure for shock, the
chief cause of disablement of soldiers in this war.
The committee's work is already
in progress and it is said that the
medical profession of two conti• nents, as well as the army authorities, believe the results to be obtained will be the most important
medical development of the conflict. They believe that if the
physiologists can find a cure for
"shell shock" the armies of the
Allies will be given a tremendous
advantage over their opponents,
an advantage that may turn the
balance of the scales.
The committee is divided—one
working in England and composed
of English scientists, and the
other working in this country
and composed of Americans. Communication between the two committees on. the daily results of
their work is frequent, and is
quite often by means of daily
cable dispatches. The object, said
Dr. Howell, is to expedite the
work as much as possible, so that
any good that may come of it can
be used to the advantage of the
armies of America and her allies
at once.
The American members of the
committee which Dr. Howell heads
are: Dr. Yandell Henderson,.professor of physiology at Yale Medical School; Dr. W. B. Cannon,
professor of physiology at Harvard Medial School and now the
American committee's representative at the base hospitals in
France, where he is making a firsthand study of conditions; Dr. Joseph Erlanger, former associate
professor of physiology at Johns
Hopkins and now head of the physiological department at Washington University, St. Louis; Dr.
Charles Claude Guthrie, professor
of physiology at the University of
Pittsburgh; Dr. Holmes C. Jackson, of New `k ork; and Dr. Frank
H. Pike, of Columbia University,
New York.
The medical profession has not
yet definitely determined the actual cause of "shell shock," and if
the Howell committee finds this
it is believed that it will lead to
(Continued on page 6, col. 4).

making themselves fitter for their
future service can still serve, and
serve now. There is very much
that you can do right now.
I would call your attention to
just one of the many ways in
which you can help, and help importantly. It is the way to insuring the absolutely necessary food
supply to ourselves, and to our
Allies.
Especially must the matter of
the food supply of our Allies be
stressed. The vital world problem
of food is not generally understood. The popular view is too
self-centered, too selfish—to use
an ugly word. It does not look
across the sea. The back-wash of
Europe's misery does not carry to
our shores. We do not know, and
hence cannot feel, the pangs of
hunger, and pain of hunger weakness that are everywhere in Europe. They are pains felt by our
Allies as well as by our foes. We
must make this known to all our
people, that all our people may understand the great and indispensable and immediate role they
must play in this all-important
part of the war situation. You
who can readily understand must
help.
You can impress on the people
around you, and wherever you go,
the fact that the critical phase of
the world food problem is now, not
the questipn of high or low
prices, but the question of producing and saving and sending
enough food to our Allies to keep
them alive and strong and steadfast in war. The critical question
now in this war is the question of
the actual physical strength of the
fighting nations.
You can understand it, and you
can explain it. You can help us,
let the people of this country know
that our Allies depend absolutely
on us to maintain their food supply. They, themselves, simply cannot do it. If it is not done for
them by us the end of the war is
near, and it is a bad end, an inconceivably bad end. From every
American college man the country
expects the truest devotion, the
truest patriotism and the highest
service. And it will get it. You
will give it.

ing will make you a more effective
helper to your country in this time
of its emergency, ever growing
more critical. So be willing and
ready to go out, but go in no
thoughtless hurry, nor merely to
satisfy the natural restlessness of
the moment.

The Ever-Recurring Story.
Days of trial and anguish lie
immediately_ ahead. A week of
doubt, speculation and sleepless
nights has cast its shadows—with
the uncanny precision and inevitability,-(hat only an official schedule of examinations can depict—
over the snow and through the
halls of Homewood. For some,
the experienced, it has been just
a year since those messengers of
the gods—Bismarck and George—
cleared the Donovan Room -for the
rickety, two-by-one tables and the
neatly printed sets of questions
were distributed to despondent
students. For others, the uninitiated, a horrible ordeal looms up
with all the mysteries and terrors
that a freshman imagination can
devise. For still others, a chosen
few, there are memories—sweetened somewhat by age—of an ominous exodus of chairs from an expansive old lecture hall which was
only to be immediately afterward
planted with row upon row of the
same pine tables over which bent
tired and flushed faces altogether
unmindful of the consoling inscription nestling far above the
restful green curtains against the
ceiling, "Veritas vos Liberabit."

In spite of the fact that we
know that examinations are just
as inevitable as death and taxes,
and that we should do better to
spend every minute of our time to
prepare to meet them, we feel
prompted to meditate upon the
significance and utility of examinations. In regard to the utility
of examinations, we readily conclude that examinations, per se,
mean very litle or nothing. What
we cram on the eve of an examination, we rarely know two weeks
later. Examinations are at best
a convenient (for want of a better) means to an end; they are
the means employed by the faculty to test a student's knowledge
of the courses he undertakes. We
may satisfy ourselves by classifying examinations under that long
list of "necessary evils."
The significance of• exarnina:
lions lies, therefore, not in their
intrinsic, but rather in their relative value. On the eve of examinations, A brief account of the relation of examinations to University honors and privileges and traditions ought not to be out of
place. There are four subjects, intimately connected with examinations, that may be discussed.
First, the Phi Beta Kappa. Phi
Beta Kappa is a national, honorary organization, membership in
which is based upon excellence in
scholarship. The fact that seven
of the last nine Presidents of the
United States werePhi Beta Kappa men may mean something more
than a mere coincidence. A student's average for the entire four
years forms the basis of eligibility
into this society. The time to set
out for a Phi Beta Kappa key is
in your freshman year,—a poor
average for his first year cost
many a man his chances for honors. A Phi Beta Kappa key
means much more than an attractive watch-charm.
Second, the Omicron Delta Kappa. The Omicron Delta Kappa is
an honorary fraternity, a chapter
of which was recently founded at
Hopkins, and membership in
which is one of the highest honors
accorded to a student qt the University. Excellence in scholarship
is one of the five bases upon which
a student becomes eligible for
membership. The Omicron Delta
Kappa key is an honor worthy of
the best efforts of every student.
Third, the Hopkins scholarships. At the end of each year,
the University awards to the members of each class four competitive scholarships covering the
tuition fee for one year. These
scholarships are based on. the average for the year's work. The
material reward for excellence in
scholarships is added to the high
honor of being a Hopkins scholar.
Fourth, the blacklist.
The
blacklist is at the same time the
most popular and the most unpopular outgrowth of the examinations. Among the rules of the
University there lurks: "No stu-

dent shall be a member of or a
candidate for an athletic team, or
a ?musical or dramatic club if his
scholarship overage on the preceding official record is below 7."
That is, in plain terms, the blacklist—the bane of the athletic
teams and all student activities.
That the blacklist is absolutely
inflexible and unyielding may be
verified by the captain of any
team. The blacklist is the most
eloquent and effective reminder
you will meet that scholarships is
primary, supreme, at Johns Hopkins, and that student activities
—however desirable and beneficial
—are secondary, subordinate. To
be on the blacklist is to be
stamped as unworthy of affiliation
with the Joh,ns Hopkins University.

to the members of the University.

Wants More Coal Saved.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir — The order issued a few
days ago by the Fuel Administrator is so expansive that it includes
our Uniirersity among the institutions which must close on ten
consecutive Mondays beginning
with January 21. The object of
this order is to save fuel. It is
designed to add another day besides Saturday on which all coal
beyond absolute needs might be
saved, not that all ,fuel saving •
might be concentrated upon one
day. Dr. Garfield and others in
position to recognize the gravity
of affairs, after complete investigation of current needs, fully understand the present and future
demands upon our fuel resources;
therefore, they have promulgated
these drastic measures.
It seems to me that the University has entirely misinterpreted
the meaning of Dr. Garfield's orders. In shifting Monday's classes
to Saturday the authorities seem
to have forgotten that the object
is to add another extra day on
which fuel may be saved. The
point is to have'Monday an extra
day, not a substitute day. On
Saturday numerous rooms of all
three of our buildings need no
heat. This fact allows fuel for at
least one-half a day te be saved.
By closing the buildings likewise
on Monday perhaps another halfday's fuel might be saved. The argument is advanced that the University has sufficient coal to last
six or eight weeks. Why "shut
down" with this supply on hand?
That is not the question. When
our present supply is exhausted
we will need more. Why not do
as our Government orders and
make our coal on hand last as long
as possible so that we will not
need to procure more and thus
scant private families?
I hope my motive in writing
this letter is not misunderstood.
The students are not greedy for
holidays. The student body fully
appreciates the duty of working
diligently at their studies—an ob1 igation which the Government
has placed upon them—and that
they will expend every energy for
the fulfillment of this due, there
is now no doubt. They would be
willing to spend a few extra weeks
at the University at the end of
the year if by doing so they can
further the cause of their country. But the students do want
their Alma Mater to co-operate

with the Government not only in
one or two ways, but in every way.
Under the present orders it seems
that we are trying to evade the
law. We have never shirked our
duty; we must not do so now.
Our traditions must be upheld.
And,then, there is the greater purpose—Germany must be defeated.
No shirking. No slacking. Let's
all get behind Uncle Sam, not only
in letter, bust in spirit, and do our
share. Save coal and defeat Germany.
EDMUND L. GETTIER, JR.,'20.
January 24, 1918.
Zionist Society Organized.

At a meeting of the Jewish students of the University in the Donovan room on last Thursday, after
an interesting address by Israel
B. Brodie, a well-known member
of the Baltimore Bar, plans were
formulated whereby students interested in Zionism will be able to
study the subject by means of lectures to be given by some of the
foremost Zionists in the United
States.
Great interest was shown at the
meeting. In his address Mr.
Brodie told how the great nations
of the world have thrown down
the gage to the Jewish people.
Discussing the manifesto of the
British Government, the declaration of the Serbian Government,
and President Wilson's statement
that there must be full autonomy
among the separate nationalities
in the Turkish Empire as a step
toward peace, Mr. Brodie pointed
out that the period was one of the
most momentous since the beginning of the Jewish dispersion
2,000 years ago. The keynote of
the address was the importance of
organization.
Dr. David S. Blondheim, of the
University faculty, was unanimously elected honorary president
of the newly organized society.
Adolf Hamburger was elected
president; Henry Miller, vice-president; I. A. Siegel, secretary; William Bloom, treasurer; Aaron
Baroway, Dr. Scaffer, Maurice
Glick, and Abraham Fedder, members of the executive committee.

BEWARE! BLOODY :TIMES AHEAD
Sergt. Kistler Supervises Training of
Daring Musketeers in Art of Fencing—Don't Pick Fights With
Sophomores!

The first class in fencing was
held Wednesday, January 23, at 4
P. M. under Sergeant Kistler, instructor in the R. 0. T. C. Eleven
stalwart sophomores, already wellversed in many bloodthirsty and
murderous arts—as the freshmen
will attest—presented themselves
for instruction.
About three times this number
had given in their names as being
interested in fencing, and it is expected that in the future the
classes will be much better attended. These classes, which must
be attended in uniform, are given
every Wednesday and Friday from
4 to 6 o'clock. From 6 to 10
men will finally be selected
as battalion fencing instructors
for the latter part of this year and
also for following years. These
men, will, moreover, form a nucleus, around which to build a
fencing team that will probably
next year meet the teams of the
large colleges and also the Naval
and Military academies. Hence,
there is a big work cut out for the
battalion, and especially the sophomores, from whom it is preferred
that the fencing instructors be selected.
Mr. Kistler uses the methods
employed at the Naval Academy,
and puts the candidates through a
thorough workout. They were
first drilled till proficient in the
six positions preliminary to "on
guard," then in advancing, retreating, extending, and lunging.
When these movements had been
practiced, the embryo fencers were
paired off—the lucky ones using
foils and the rest wooden wands—
and shown the different engagements where to thrust and how to
parry. As there were no freshmen
present, no bloodshed ensued, but
the next morning several of the
fencers complained vigorously of
stiff backs and knees.
After foil work will ccime broadsword and bayonet practice, the
latter so especially needed by our
future soldiers. When the use of
the foil has been mastered with
the right hand, the fencers will,
for the sake of practice and exercise, wield the weapon with the
left. Lessons from a text book will
be later assigned. Thus, it is
planned to institute a very thorough course in fencing in the battalion.

The College Student and the War
By HERBERT HOOVER
United States Food Administrator.

(From the Patriotic News Service of
the National Committee of Patriotic
Societies, Washington, D. C.)

To the college men of America I
address myself with confidence, a
confidence born of unforgettable
experience.
In the relief of Belgium most of
the actual work of the Commission in the occupied territory was
done by young American collegians. Each time a call was
made for volunteers many more
than asked for offered their services. And those that were chosen
performed their duties, not only
effectively, but with a spirit of devotion that made their service beyond praise. They combined idealism and efficiency. It is the combination that moves the world forward.
Today all the young college men
of America face,a special responsibility and duty. At no time in the
world's history has the technically
trained mind been at a higher premium. And this need for it and
demand on it will continue after
the war is over. Hence the young
man in college is faced with a serious problem. He must ask hinrself: Is the immediate need of me
by my country in my present stage
of training greater than this need
will be later, and when I have acquired a higher training? This is
a question the clear answer to
which cannot be indicated for all
by a single formula,..because the
young men in college find themselves under varying circumstances. Yet an answer in general
terms of some helpfulness may be
made.
To the younger men, the lower
classmen, only beginning their
professional training, I say: Keep
on with your college work. If the
war lasts long you will be needed
more later than now; and you
will be better qualified to fill the
need then. If the war ends soon
there will still be urgent need for
your help in the necessary great
work of reconstruction and rehabilitation. The moreadvancedyour
training, the more mature your
judgment, the more valuable you
• will be. So try to possess yourself
in patience and stick to your college work.
To the upper classmen I would
say: Hold yourself ready to respond to your country's present
need at any moment. Where you
see your way clear to make your
training useful do not hesitate to
follow the way. But you, too,
should remember that every additional month or semester of train(Continued on page 2, col. 2)

Dr. William H. Howell, professor of physiology at the Medical
School and assistant to Dr. William H. Welch in the direction of
the new Institute of Hygiene and
Public Health, has been selected
to head a committee of eminent
physiologists of America and England, appointed to try to find the
cause and a cure for shock, the
chief cause of disablement of soldiers in this war.
The committee's work is already
in progress and it is said that the
medical profession of two conti• nents, as well as the army authorities, believe the results to be obtained will be the most important
medical development of the conflict. They believe that if the
physiologists can find a cure for
"shell shock" the armies of the
Allies will be given a tremendous
advantage over their opponents,
an advantage that may turn the
balance of the scales.
The committee is divided—one
working in England and composed
of English scientists, and the
other working in this country
and composed of Americans. Communication between the two committees on. the daily results of
their work is frequent, and is
quite often by means of daily
cable dispatches. The object, said
Dr. Howell, is to expedite the
work as much as possible, so that
any good that may come of it can
be used to the advantage of the
armies of America and her allies
at once.
The American members of the
committee which Dr. Howell heads
are: Dr. Yandell Henderson,.professor of physiology at Yale Medical School; Dr. W. B. Cannon,
professor of physiology at Harvard Medial School and now the
American committee's representative at the base hospitals in
France, where he is making a firsthand study of conditions; Dr. Joseph Erlanger, former associate
professor of physiology at Johns
Hopkins and now head of the physiological department at Washington University, St. Louis; Dr.
Charles Claude Guthrie, professor
of physiology at the University of
Pittsburgh; Dr. Holmes C. Jackson, of New `k ork; and Dr. Frank
H. Pike, of Columbia University,
New York.
The medical profession has not
yet definitely determined the actual cause of "shell shock," and if
the Howell committee finds this
it is believed that it will lead to

making themselves fitter for their

serve now. There is very much
that you can do right now.
I would call your attention to
just one of the many ways in
which you can help, and help importantly. It is the way to insuring the absolutely necessary food
supply to ourselves, and to our
Allies.
Especially must the matter of
the food supply of our Allies be
stressed. The vital world problem
of food is not generally understood. The popular view is too
self-centered, too selfish—to use
an ugly word. It does not look
across the sea. The back-wash of
Europe's misery does not carry to
our shores. We do not know, and
hence cannot feel, the pangs of
hunger, and pain of hunger weakness that are everywhere in Europe. They are pains felt by our
Allies as well as by our foes. We
must make this known to all our
people, that all our people may understand the great and indispensable and immediate role they
must play in this all-important
part of the war situation. You
who can readily understand must
help.
You can impress on the people
around you, and wherever you go,
the fact that the critical phase of
the world food problem is now, not
the questipn of high or low
prices, but the question of producing and saving and sending
enough food to our Allies to keep
them alive and strong and steadfast in war. The critical question
now in this war is the question of
the actual physical strength of the
fighting nations.
You can understand it, and you
can explain it. You can help us,
let the people of this country know
that our Allies depend absolutely

The Ever-Recurring Story.
Days of trial and anguish lie
immediately_ ahead. A week of
doubt, speculation and sleepless
nights has cast its shadows—with
the uncanny precision and inevitability,-(hat only an official schedule of examinations can depict—
over the snow and through the
halls of Homewood. For some,
the experienced, it has been just
a year since those messengers of
the gods—Bismarck and George—
cleared the Donovan Room -for the
rickety, two-by-one tables and the
neatly printed sets of questions
were distributed to despondent
students. For others, the uninitiated, a horrible ordeal looms up
with all the mysteries and terrors
that a freshman imagination can
devise. For still others, a chosen
few, there are memories—sweetened somewhat by age—of an ominous exodus of chairs from an expansive old lecture hall which was
only to be immediately afterward
planted with row upon row of the
same pine tables over which bent
tired and flushed faces altogether
unmindful of the consoling inscription nestling far above the
restful green curtains against the
ceiling, "Veritas vos Liberabit."

In spite of the fact that we
know that examinations are just
as inevitable as death and taxes,
and that we should do better to
spend every minute of our time to
prepare to meet them, we feel
prompted to meditate upon the
significance and utility of examinations. In regard to the utility
of examinations, we readily conclude that examinations, per se,
mean very litle or nothing. What
we cram on the eve of an examination, we rarely know two weeks
later. Examinations are at best
a convenient (for want of a better) means to an end; they are
the means employed by the faculty to test a student's knowledge
of the courses he undertakes. We
may satisfy ourselves by classifying examinations under that long
list of "necessary evils."
The significance of• exarnina:
lions lies, therefore, not in their
intrinsic, but rather in their relative value. On the eve of examinations, A brief account of the relation of examinations to University honors and privileges and traditions ought not to be out of
place. There are four subjects, intimately connected with examinations, that may be discussed.
First, the Phi Beta Kappa. Phi
Beta Kappa is a national, honorary organization, membership in
which is based upon excellence in
scholarship. The fact that seven
of the last nine Presidents of the
United States werePhi Beta Kappa men may mean something more
than a mere coincidence. A student's average for the entire four
years forms the basis of eligibility
into this society. The time to set
out for a Phi Beta Kappa key is
in your freshman year,—a poor
average for his first year cost
many a man his chances for honors. A Phi Beta Kappa key
means much more than an attractive watch-charm.
Second, the Omicron Delta Kappa. The Omicron Delta Kappa is
an honorary fraternity, a chapter
of which was recently founded at
Hopkins, and membership in
which is one of the highest honors
accorded to a student qt the University. Excellence in scholarship
is one of the five bases upon which
a student becomes eligible for
membership. The Omicron Delta
Kappa key is an honor worthy of
the best efforts of every student.
Third, the Hopkins scholarships. At the end of each year,
the University awards to the members of each class four competitive scholarships covering the
tuition fee for one year. These
scholarships are based on. the average for the year's work. The
material reward for excellence in
scholarships is added to the high
honor of being a Hopkins scholar.
Fourth, the blacklist.
The
blacklist is at the same time the
most popular and the most unpopular outgrowth of the examinations. Among the rules of the
University there lurks: "No stu-

dent shall be a member of or a
candidate for an athletic team, or
a ?musical or dramatic club if his
scholarship overage on the preceding official record is below 7."
That is, in plain terms, the blacklist—the bane of the athletic
teams and all student activities.
That the blacklist is absolutely
inflexible and unyielding may be
verified by the captain of any
team. The blacklist is the most
eloquent and effective reminder
you will meet that scholarships is
primary, supreme, at Johns Hopkins, and that student activities
—however desirable and beneficial
—are secondary, subordinate. To
be on the blacklist is to be
stamped as unworthy of affiliation
with the Joh,ns Hopkins University.

In,commemoration of Dr.Franklin Paine Mall, late professor of
anatOmy in the Medical School,
there will be held a meeting in the
Civil Engineering Building on
Sunday afternoon, February 3, at

President Goodnow will preside
at the meeting, at which some of

William H. Welch, director, of the
School of Hygiene and -Public
Health; Dr. Simon Flexner, of the

to the members of the University.

Wants More Coal Saved.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir — The order issued a few
days ago by the Fuel Administrator is so expansive that it includes
our Uniirersity among the institutions which must close on ten
consecutive Mondays beginning
with January 21. The object of
this order is to save fuel. It is
designed to add another day besides Saturday on which all coal
beyond absolute needs might be
saved, not that all ,fuel saving •
might be concentrated upon one
day. Dr. Garfield and others in
position to recognize the gravity
of affairs, after complete investigation of current needs, fully understand the present and future
demands upon our fuel resources;
therefore, they have promulgated
these drastic measures.
It seems to me that the University has entirely misinterpreted
the meaning of Dr. Garfield's orders. In shifting Monday's classes
to Saturday the authorities seem
to have forgotten that the object
is to add another extra day on
which fuel may be saved. The
point is to have'Monday an extra
day, not a substitute day. On
Saturday numerous rooms of all
three of our buildings need no
heat. This fact allows fuel for at
least one-half a day te be saved.
By closing the buildings likewise
on Monday perhaps another halfday's fuel might be saved. The argument is advanced that the University has sufficient coal to last
six or eight weeks. Why "shut
down" with this supply on hand?
That is not the question. When
our present supply is exhausted
we will need more. Why not do
as our Government orders and
make our coal on hand last as long
as possible so that we will not
need to procure more and thus
scant private families?
I hope my motive in writing
this letter is not misunderstood.
The students are not greedy for
holidays. The student body fully
appreciates the duty of working
diligently at their studies—an ob1 igation which the Government
has placed upon them—and that
they will expend every energy for
the fulfillment of this due, there
is now no doubt. They would be
willing to spend a few extra weeks
at the University at the end of
the year if by doing so they can
further the cause of their country. But the students do want
their Alma Mater to co-operate

with the Government not only in
one or two ways, but in every way.
Under the present orders it seems
that we are trying to evade the
law. We have never shirked our
duty; we must not do so now.
Our traditions must be upheld.
And,then, there is the greater purpose—Germany must be defeated.
No shirking. No slacking. Let's
all get behind Uncle Sam, not only
in letter, bust in spirit, and do our
share. Save coal and defeat Germany.
EDMUND L. GETTIER, JR.,'20.
January 24, 1918.
Zionist Society Organized.

At a meeting of the Jewish students of the University in the Donovan room on last Thursday, after
an interesting address by Israel
B. Brodie, a well-known member
of the Baltimore Bar, plans were
formulated whereby students interested in Zionism will be able to
study the subject by means of lectures to be given by some of the
foremost Zionists in the United
States.
Great interest was shown at the
meeting. In his address Mr.
Brodie told how the great nations
of the world have thrown down
the gage to the Jewish people.
Discussing the manifesto of the
British Government, the declaration of the Serbian Government,
and President Wilson's statement
that there must be full autonomy
among the separate nationalities
in the Turkish Empire as a step
toward peace, Mr. Brodie pointed
out that the period was one of the
most momentous since the beginning of the Jewish dispersion
2,000 years ago. The keynote of
the address was the importance of
organization.
Dr. David S. Blondheim, of the
University faculty, was unanimously elected honorary president
of the newly organized society.
Adolf Hamburger was elected
president; Henry Miller, vice-president; I. A. Siegel, secretary; William Bloom, treasurer; Aaron
Baroway, Dr. Scaffer, Maurice
Glick, and Abraham Fedder, members of the executive committee.

BEWARE! BLOODY :TIMES AHEAD
Sergt. Kistler Supervises Training of
Daring Musketeers in Art of Fencing—Don't Pick Fights With
Sophomores!

The first class in fencing was
held Wednesday, January 23, at 4
P. M. under Sergeant Kistler, instructor in the R. 0. T. C. Eleven
stalwart sophomores, already wellversed in many bloodthirsty and
murderous arts—as the freshmen
will attest—presented themselves
for instruction.
About three times this number
had given in their names as being
interested in fencing, and it is expected that in the future the
classes will be much better attended. These classes, which must
be attended in uniform, are given
every Wednesday and Friday from
4 to 6 o'clock. From 6 to 10
men will finally be selected
as battalion fencing instructors
for the latter part of this year and
also for following years. These
men, will, moreover, form a nucleus, around which to build a
fencing team that will probably
next year meet the teams of the
large colleges and also the Naval
and Military academies. Hence,
there is a big work cut out for the
battalion, and especially the sophomores, from whom it is preferred
that the fencing instructors be selected.
Mr. Kistler uses the methods
employed at the Naval Academy,
and puts the candidates through a
thorough workout. They were
first drilled till proficient in the
six positions preliminary to "on
guard," then in advancing, retreating, extending, and lunging.
When these movements had been
practiced, the embryo fencers were
paired off—the lucky ones using
foils and the rest wooden wands—
and shown the different engagements where to thrust and how to
parry. As there were no freshmen
present, no bloodshed ensued, but
the next morning several of the
fencers complained vigorously of
stiff backs and knees.
After foil work will ccime broadsword and bayonet practice, the
latter so especially needed by our
future soldiers. When the use of
the foil has been mastered with
the right hand, the fencers will,
for the sake of practice and exercise, wield the weapon with the
left. Lessons from a text book will
be later assigned. Thus, it is
planned to institute a very thorough course in fencing in the battalion.
